title: who then blasts 'b***shit' insinuations
text:

Laura Muir fell short in her bid to become Britain’s third world champion in six days – beaten by an athlete competing under a “black cloud”, writes Alex Spink in Doha.

Despite clocking one of her fastest-ever times, Muir could finish only fifth, with Sifan Hassan making history as the first woman to complete the 1500m and 10,000m double.

“I don’t know what to say,” said Muir. “I was fifth in 3:55!”

The Scot’s shock was echoed by former men’s 1500m world champion Steve Cram, who looked at the clock and said: “You are kidding me.”

Dutch star Hassan – who won in a championship record 3:51.95 – is coached by Alberto Salazar, banned for four years last week for multiple doping violations.

(Image: PA)

Before the race, the mile world-record holder claimed to have a “clear conscience” as the Salazar probe was focused on a period before she joined his Oregon Project.

But Muir, who lost six weeks of training to a calf tear in July, said: “Given the news of the past few days, there is a cloud. There’s no avoiding that.”

Hassan raged: “This is what makes me angry. I have been clean all my life. This makes me so mad.

(Image: Getty Images for IAAF)

"I have been on top for almost five months. How can I do these things that they say? I have been such a good athlete since 2014.

"Now people start talking all this bullshit. I am sorry for my language. It has been a hard week for me.

“I couldn't talk to anyone. I ran all out. I wanted to show that hard work can beat everything.”

(Image: DIEGO AZUBEL/EPA-EFE/REX)

Earlier in the week US star Jenny Simpson had said a “black shadow, a black cloud, whatever analogy you want to make” hung over Salazar’s group.

IAAF president Sebastian Coe has instructed athletes coached by Salazar to sever links immediately. Olympic boss Thomas Bach has demanded the World Anti-Doping Agency investigate them all.

Speaking on BBC, track legend Michael Johnson said: "People in this sport, fans of this sport, are so sick and tired of drug cheats in this sport, they have had it, they have zero tolerance at this point.

(Image: Clive Mason/Getty Images)

"So if you are associated with a coach that’s been banned, if you miss your whereabouts filings, if you test positive or have any sort of connection to anything dealing with doping, they are done with you.

"That’s just the way it is - and these athletes need to understand that."

Abigail Irozuru caps a stunning comeback today when she competes in the final of the women’s long jump, three years after retiring at the age of 26, weary of serious injuries.

After easily qualifying she said: “I’m here and I’m one of the best in the world and that is a crazy thing to say.”

Shara Proctor also qualified but four-time world champ Brittney Reese went out.
